issue.title: Julia cannot unlink hall of fame files (resource busy or locked)
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
When running `model.fit()`, the process will stop at a seemingly random iteration number.  This may be due to collisions between workers when using `multithreading=False`.  The issue can surface at any time during the run.

**Version (please include the following information):**
- OS: Windows 11
- Julia version 1.7.3
- Python version 3.10.5
- PySR version 0.9.3
- Does the bug still appear with the latest version of PySR? **yes**

**Configuration**

```python
#import libs
import numpy as np
from pysr import PySRRegressor
from matplotlib import pyplot as plt
import pandas as pd

#import data from csv
data = pd.read_csv (r'C:\Users\matth\PycharmProjects\psrig\7209fa.csv')
df=pd.DataFrame(data, columns=['x1','p1','p2','p3','p4','p5''])

#model setup
model = PySRRegressor(
    model_selection="best",  # Result is mix of simplicity+accuracy
    niterations=1000,
    multithreading=False,
    procs=24,
    populations=48,
    population_size=96,
    update=False,
    complexity_of_constants=2,
    
    binary_operators=["+", "*","/","-"],
    unary_operators=[
        "exp"
    ],
    loss="loss(x, y) = (x - y)^2",
    # ^ Custom loss function (julia syntax)
)
#run the fit
model.fit(X,y)
```

**Error message**

Jupyter output:
```Python
C:\Users\user\PycharmProjects\pythonProject12\venv\lib\site-packages\pysr\sr.py:1067: UserWarning: Note: it looks like you are running in Jupyter. The progress bar will be turned off.

-> 1606 return self._run(X, y, mutated_params, weights=weights, seed=seed)
```

Completely reinstalled python, pycharm and julia.

nodes.body: **Some additional info:** All of the Julia worker processes remain in memory afterwards. Executing `model.fit(X,y)` again launches new worker processes while the old ones persist.  The 24 workers in my use case occupy about 400 MB each, meaning each time the fit process was restarted, about 10GB of additional memory would be occupied.  This can be worked around by stopping execution in the terminal with [q] [enter].
Do you see the same issue when launching a Python script directly from terminal, or do you only see this in Jupyter?

Just tested: same error (to my eyes)

```python
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "C:\Users\user\PycharmProjects\pythonProject12\main.py", line 60, in <module>

    @ SymbolicRegression C:\Users\user\.julia\packages\SymbolicRegression\nlE1i\src\SymbolicRegression.jl:762
```

Thanks for running that.

It looks like this error has been seen by others copying files on windows from Julia: https://discourse.julialang.org/t/ioerror-unlink-resource-busy-or-locked-ebusy-in-windows/32045?u=milescranmer. I wonder what causes it in PySR... here is the [line the copy is called: ](
https://github.com/MilesCranmer/SymbolicRegression.jl/blob/0055b3461616bc380c0e6dd1ab96103e866ae006/src/SymbolicRegression.jl#L764)
```python
cp(hofFile, hofFile * ".bkup"; force=true)
```
(the syntax `hofFile * ".bkup"` just means concatenate ".bkup" with the filename)

Nothing seems to unusual about this line... I wonder if it wants me to remove the file first, before copying a new file to it?

I'm thinking this may be a windows 11 mystery issue now - I've run the above code to 100% 3 times now and it didn't crash.  Ran it a 4th time and it did... 

 If pysr / julia aren't locking the file and then trying to write to it, the collision must be with something else like the windows file system or built in security processes.  I have indexing turned off so it's not likely to be that.

You said it happens randomly, correct? I wonder if it has to do with PyCharm trying to read the file since it is in your directory, and then PyCharm's read vs. Julia's write being in conflict.

Can you try re-running but with `temp_equation_file=True`? This will save the equation file to a temporary folder, away from processes which might try to read it.
Pycharm has a setting to "ignore files", which protects them from indexing... I wonder if this is the reason why.
Running 3 hours now and seems totally stable.  Thanks @MilesCranmer , I really appreciate your help! (and pysr) ðŸ™ƒ

Awesome! Glad to hear this fixed it. Just so I know the fix for future improvements, was it the `temp_equation_file`, or was it setting PyCharm to ignore files? 
Happy to hear you're enjoying PySR, please spread the word :)

Cheers,
Miles
`temp_equation_file=TRUE` did it.  I didn't test the ignore setting
